perturbation.original_text:
8.2  Termination for Failure to Perform.  By providing written notice, a
party may immediately terminate this Agreement: (a) if the other party
materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure that breach within 15 days
after receiving written notice of the breach, or (b) as provided in Sections 2.6  [Boxlot Content]
or 12.7  [Force Majeure] or Exhibit B.  In addition, by providing written notice, theglobe may
immediately terminate this Agreement, or at its option immediately suspend its
promotion and other efforts hereunder, in the case of Boxlot's breach of Section
12.1  [Compliance with Laws].
perturbation.changed_text: 8.2  Termination for Failure to Perform. By providing written notice, a party may terminate this Agreement: (a) if the other party materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure that breach within 5 days after receiving written notice of the breach, or (b) as provided in Sections 2.6 [Boxlot Content] or 12.7 [Force Majeure] or Exhibit B. In addition, by providing written notice, theglobe may terminate this Agreement, or at its option immediately suspend its promotion and other efforts hereunder, in the case of Boxlot's breach of Section 12.1 [Compliance with Laws].
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach from 15 days to 5 days may be considered unconscionable or violate implied duties of good faith and fair dealing in some jurisdictions, especially if the breach requires significant effort to remedy. Courts often look unfavorably on clauses that provide unreasonably short cure periods, especially in complex commercial agreements. This may introduce legal challenges.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied duty of good faith and fair dealing; potential unconscionability under UCC 2-302 (applicable to contracts for the sale of goods, but can be used as an analogous principle in other contract contexts).

perturbation.original_text:
6.1  Payments.  The parties shall make the payments described in Exhibit A.
Overdue payments shall accrue interest, at the lesser of 1 1/2% per month or the
maximum allowable interest under applicable law, from due date until paid, and
the owing party shall pay the owed party's costs of collection (including
reasonable attorneys' fees).
perturbation.changed_text: 6.1  Payments. The parties shall make the payments described in Exhibit A. Overdue payments shall accrue interest at 25% per month, from due date until paid, and the owing party shall pay the owed party's costs of collection (excluding attorneys' fees).
perturbation.explanation: Charging 25% interest per month on overdue payments far exceeds the usury limits in most states, rendering this provision illegal and unenforceable. Additionally, excluding attorney's fees from the costs of collection may violate state statutes that allow for the recovery of such fees in breach of contract cases.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State usury laws; state statutes regarding the recovery of attorney's fees in contract disputes.

perturbation.original_text:
4.3  Trademark Restrictions.  The Mark owner may terminate the foregoing
trademark license if, in its reasonable discretion, the licensee's use of the
Marks tarnishes, blurs or dilutes the quality associated with the Marks or the
associated goodwill and such problem is not cured within 10 days of notice of
breach; alternatively, instead of terminating the license in total, the owner
may specify that certain licensee uses may not contain the Marks.  Title to and
ownership of the owner's Marks shall remain with the owner.  The licensee shall
use the Marks exactly in the form provided and in conformance with any trademark
usage policies.  The licensee shall not take any action inconsistent with the
owner's ownership of the Marks, and any benefits accruing from use of such Marks
shall automatically vest in the owner.  The licensee shall not form any
combination marks with the other party's Marks other than the Domain Name (if
applicable).  If the Domain Name is deemed a combination mark, neither party
shall use the Domain Name for any purpose except as expressly provided herein or
attempt to register the Domain Name, and the parties will jointly cooperate on
any enforcement action of infringement of the Domain Name.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.3  Trademark Restrictions. The Mark owner may terminate the foregoing trademark license if, in its reasonable discretion, the licensee's use of the Marks tarnishes the quality associated with the Marks or the associated goodwill and such problem is not cured within 24 hours of notice of breach; alternatively, instead of terminating the license in total, the owner may specify that certain licensee uses may not contain the Marks. Title to and ownership of the owner's Marks shall remain with the owner. The licensee shall use the Marks exactly in the form provided and in conformance with any trademark usage policies. The licensee shall not take any action inconsistent with the owner's ownership of the Marks, and any benefits accruing from use of such Marks shall automatically vest in the owner. The licensee shall not form any combination marks with the other party's Marks other than the Domain Name (if applicable). If the Domain Name is deemed a combination mark, neither party shall use the Domain Name for any purpose except as expressly provided herein or attempt to register the Domain Name, and the parties will jointly cooperate on any enforcement action of infringement of the Domain Name.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for trademark tarnishment from 10 days to 24 hours is unreasonable and likely insufficient for addressing complex trademark issues. This could be deemed an unfair business practice and violate principles of equity, potentially conflicting with the Lanham Act's emphasis on fair competition and consumer protection.
perturbation.contradicted_law: The Lanham Act (15 U.S.C. § 1125); principles of equity and fair business practices.
